channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Confusion and Frustration Reign as Elon Musk Cuts Half of Twitter’s Staff
item.description: The layoffs hit across many divisions, including the engineering and machine learning units, the teams that manage content moderation, and the sales and advertising departments.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Ryan Mac and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Friday morning, at least nine security guards were seen patrolling Twitter headquarters in San Francisco. Employees had been told to stay home as layoffs were carried out.

item.title: How an LAPD Officer Helped Les Moonves Fight an Assault Complaint
item.description: A captain in the department, who had moonlighted as a security guard for CBS, disclosed to the network information about a confidential complaint made in 2017 against the C.E.O.
item.dc:creator: James B. Stewart and Rachel Abrams
item.media:description: The Los Angeles Police Department has opened an investigation into the conduct of Cory Palka, who is now retired.

item.title: Fed Up With Political Text Messages? Read On.
item.description: In this polarized climate, hundreds of Americans told us they agree on one thing: Campaigns must stop spamming voters’ phones with unwanted political texts.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer

item.title: YouTube May Have Misinformation Blind Spots, Researchers Say
item.description: The video platform said it had limited the spread of misinformation ahead of Election Day, but new research showed that false narratives continued to slip through.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant
item.media:description: The nonprofit Media Matters identified a variety of videos on YouTube that contained misinformation.

item.title: Berkshire Hathaway Reports Third-Quarter Loss
item.description: The company’s huge investment portfolio lost money, while its insurance arm felt the effects of Hurricane Ian and inflation-driven rises in property and damage claims.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:description: Warren Buffett, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, earlier this year. The company’s third-quarter earnings highlighted how much it is a microcosm of the American economy.

item.title: Twitter’s Advertisers Pull Back as Layoffs Sweep Through Company
item.description: Elon Musk, Twitter’s new owner, acknowledged that ad spending on the platform had slumped. He blamed the drop on pressure from activists.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu
item.media:description: More companies have paused their spending on Twitter out of concern that their ads could appear alongside problematic content.

item.title: On Social Media, Hunting for Voter Fraud Becomes a Game
item.description: Players who post about irregularities are awarded points or titles, leading participants to question the legitimacy of elections.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: A woman monitored a ballot drop box in a parking lot in Mesa, Ariz., on Oct. 24. Hunting for voter fraud has become a game on social media.

item.title: Expect Higher Health Insurance Premiums, but Not a Lot Higher
item.description: Benefit costs may go up as much as 6 percent. Wary of driving workers away, many employers may not pass on the full increases, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

item.title: What Will the Midterms Mean for Big Business?
item.description: The G.O.P. and corporate America, longtime allies, are showing signs of a breakup — which recent polls suggest will likely play out with a Republican House.
item.dc:creator: Joe Nocera

item.title: Medicare Advantage or Just Medicare?
item.description: It’s annual enrollment season once again. Here’s a look at the pros and cons of the two approaches to health insurance.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The proportion of eligible Medicare beneficiaries enrolled in Medicare Advantage plans will exceed 50 percent next year, experts estimate.

item.title: Fed Frets About Shadow Banks and Eyes Treasury Liquidity in New Report
item.description: The Federal Reserve is watching the government bond market and investment funds as rate increases ricochet through finance.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal Reserve building in Washington. As policymakers remain determined to push ahead with efforts to slow the economy, they are keeping a careful eye on market conditions.

item.title: GOP Lawmakers Question Amtrak Over Six-Figure Bonuses
item.description: Two Republicans on the House Transportation Committee asked the rail service to explain how it awards bonuses after top executives received payouts of more than $200,000 each last year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:description: The lawmakers’ letter was sent after a report by The New York Times revealed that Amtrak paid out $2.3 million in short-term incentive bonuses to top executives despite reporting its lowest revenue and biggest losses in more than a decade.

item.title: Biden Spins His Economic Record Ahead of Elections
item.description: The president’s recent comments on Social Security, the deficit and economic growth claim credit where it is not always due.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: White House officials have sometimes been forced to awkwardly correct President Biden’s claims. Other times, they have doubled down on them.

item.title: Germany’s Leader Seeks Accord With China on Covid Vaccines
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz said during a visit to Beijing that China and the European Union were working toward approval of each other’s pandemic vaccines.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz, met with President Xi Jinping of China in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: James Giffen, Who Was Embroiled in ‘Kazakhgate,’ Dies at 81
item.description: The government charged him with funneling $78 million in bribes to Kazakhstan, but dropped the case after a judge decided he had acted with C.I.A. approval.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: James H. Giffen in 2000. His merchant bank was a go-between for Western energy companies eager to exploit Kazakhstan’s vast oil fields. “He was Washington’s de facto ambassador to Kazakhstan,” a former C.I.A. official said.

item.title: Forecasting the Future of Election Prediction Markets
item.description: After flying under the radar as academic experiments, the markets are facing close regulatory scrutiny. But they are worth preserving, our columnist says.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:description: Traders on the Curb Market, a rollicking outdoor marketplace in New York for stocks, bonds and politics, in the 1920s.

item.title: Twitter Begins Laying Off Employees
item.description: Employees of the social network will learn via email if they are out of a job — or if they will continue to work for Elon Musk.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Mostly in the dark.

item.title: U.S. Added 261,000 Jobs in Strong Showing
item.description: Job growth is slowing but remains stronger than comfortable for the Federal Reserve, which is trying to tame high inflation.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember

item.title: In Bid to Show It Is Open, Hong Kong Bends Covid Rules … for Some
item.description: Three splashy events this week were meant to prove that the former British colony was still “Asia’s World City.” But Covid exemptions were provided for visitors from overseas, especially the wealthy ones.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Louise Delmotte for The New York Times

item.title: The Vegan Butchers Carving Your Thanksgiving Turkey
item.description: Price of turkey got you down? How about roast beef, meatloaf, or brats. Thanks to these vegan butchers, you can have any cut of “meat” you want at Thanksgiving this year.
item.dc:creator: Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg

item.title: Workers Expect Fast Inflation Next Year. Could That Make It a Reality?
item.description: The Federal Reserve chair is eyeing near-term inflation expectations, which might shape wages — and help keep prices rising rapidly.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Officials are worried that as Americans expect prices to rise rapidly, they will also ask for higher wages — the kind of behavior that could turn today’s price burst into a more intractable problem.

item.title: Five Ways Sanctions Are Hitting Russia
item.description: Russia’s economy and residents have taken a battering, but the government continues to reap big revenues from energy sales. A partial European embargo on oil takes effect in December.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Ana Swanson and Michael Crowley
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A closed Zara store in Moscow. Russian imports have dropped sharply, reflecting the decision of multinational companies to sever ties with Russia.

item.title: Twitter Employees on Life Under Elon Musk
item.description: A radical shake-up is underway at the social media company.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Paula Szuchman, Corey Schreppel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Elisheba Ittoop
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration: The New York Times; Photo: Cayce Clifford for The New York Times

item.title: Worries Grow That TikTok Is New Home for Manipulated Video and Photos
item.description: Misleading edits, fake news stories and deepfake images of politicians are starting to warp reality on the popular video platform.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu
item.media:description: Manipulated media is spreading before the midterms on TikTok, whose policies prohibit digital forgeries “that mislead users by distorting the truth.”

item.title: Elon Musk Begins Layoffs at Twitter As Some Employees File Lawsuit
item.description: The social media company’s 7,500 employees have been bracing for job cuts since Mr. Musk took it over last week.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. About half the company’s 7,500 workers appeared set to lose their jobs.

item.title: Elon Musk, Under Financial Pressure, Pushes to Make Money From Twitter
item.description: The billionaire and his advisers have discussed adding paid direct messages, fees to watch videos and other features to the service.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. Last year, the company had less money in cash flow than what it now owes its lenders annually.

item.title: Battle Over Deep-Sea Mining Takes on New Urgency as Trial Run Winds Down
item.description: A Canadian company is testing mining equipment in the Pacific Ocean in its quest for metals needed for electric vehicles. Environmentalists oppose the mining, which could begin in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Charles M. Vella/SOPA Images, via LightRocket — Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters in Rotterdam projected statements onto the Hidden Gem, a ship used by the Metals Company.

item.title: CNBC Cancels Shepard Smith’s Show in Move Away From General News
item.description: Mr. Smith joined CNBC in 2020 after leaving his longtime home on Fox News, where he was a reliably nonpartisan presence.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shepard Smith’s last show at CNBC will be later this month.

item.title: UK Takes Sides Over Bounty Chocolate
item.description: Bounty, a chocolate-coconut concoction similar to Mounds, will be left out of some Celebrations holiday assortments this year, stirring a national debate.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor

item.title: Clean Energy Tax Break Draws Scrutiny of Natural Gas Plan in New Mexico
item.description: A defunct New Mexico coal plant would be revamped with the help of subsidies authorized by the new climate legislation, but a plan to rely on natural gas converted into hydrogen has generated criticism.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Adria Malcolm for The New York Times
item.media:description: A defunct coal-burning power plant in northwest New Mexico may be turned into one that derives hydrogen from natural gas for use in generating electricity.

item.title: White House Deletes Tweet Crediting Biden With Social Security Increase
item.description: The automatic cost of living increase that Social Security beneficiaries are receiving is a result of soaring inflation, not a policy achievement enacted by President Biden.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: The White House press secretary suggested that a Twitter post attributing increased Social Security payments to “President Biden’s leadership” had lacked sufficient context.

item.title: BlackRock Expands Client Voting in Shareholder Elections
item.description: The money manager said it will let more clients vote individually in companies’ elections, as it faces criticism of its own shareholder power.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: More say for all?

item.title: As Dollar Strengthens, U.S. Students in Europe Feel the Benefits
item.description: The pound and the euro are trading at decades-long lows against the dollar. For American students abroad, that has made weekend trips, dinners and theater tickets (somewhat) less of a splurge.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Avery Scott, a junior at the University of Georgia, is currently studying at the University of Oxford in England, where her money has gone further because of the falling value of the British pound.

item.title: China Is Burning More Coal, a Growing Climate Challenge
item.description: The country’s emissions of greenhouse gases rose last year at the fastest pace in a decade. Beijing is looking for alternatives.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant in Beijing. China has long viewed coal, which it has in abundance, as the best way to avoid becoming overly dependent on foreign energy suppliers.

item.title: Mortgage Rates Too High? (Blame the Fed, Wall Street and Your Neighbor.)
item.description: Lenders use several bits of data to set mortgage rates, including trading moves by investors. Without market volatility, the rate could be under 7 percent.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison and Tara Siegel Bernard
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Newly built homes in California in July. High mortgage rates have put many homes out of reach for prospective buyers.

item.title: Debt Limit Showdown Looms as White House Braces for a Divided Washington
item.description: G.O.P. threats to leverage the full faith and credit of the United States to force spending cuts have raised alarm about a debt showdown next year — and talks about how to head one off in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The fight could come to a head early next year, when the government is projected to hit its borrowing limit unless Congress can muster the votes to raise it.

item.title: Amid Forecasts of Recession, Bank of England Raises Interest Rates
item.description: With inflation above 10 percent, the central bank ramped up its fight against price increases even as it predicted a “prolonged” recession.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bank of England, like many of the world’s central banks, has been raising interest rates in the face of the highest inflation in decades.

item.title: Les Moonves and Paramount to Pay $9.75 Million in State Case Tied to Sexual Misconduct
item.description: The New York attorney general’s office found that CBS, whose parent company is now Paramount, concealed allegations about its former chief executive from investors.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Benjamin Mullin

item.title: Elon Musk Takes a Page Out of Mark Zuckerberg’s Social Media Playbook
item.description: As Mr. Musk takes over Twitter, he is emulating some of the actions of Mr. Zuckerberg, who leads Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Ryan Mac and Tiffany Hsu
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
item.media:description: Elon Musk in January 2020. As Twitter’s new owner, he met this week with civil rights groups.

item.title: Attorneys General Sue to Stop Dividend Tied to Kroger-Albertsons Deal
item.description: The suit could portend other regulatory battles to come as the supermarket chains look to close their nearly $25 billion merger.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Together, Kroger and Albertsons account for more than 5,000 grocery stores across the country.

item.title: Tumblr Reverses Nudity Ban
item.description: Reversing a 2018 ban, the company said that nudity and “mature subject matter” would be allowed. But “visual depictions of sexually explicit acts” remain off limits.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Thiago Prudencio/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images
item.media:description: The blogging site Tumblr lost about a third of its traffic after it announced in 2018 that it was banning explicit posts.

item.title: Stocks Drop As Fed Leaves Investors Uncertain About Rates
item.description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said the central bank “still has a ways to go” before it will be done raising interest rates, and that rates may go higher than previously anticipated.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, and his colleagues have been rapidly increasing interest rates this year to try to wrestle inflation lower.

item.title: Campaigns Skirt Political Ad Rules by Paying Influencers
item.description: Campaigns are using social media influencers as a way to reach young and diverse voters, a novel and mostly unregulated strategy. Some are even spreading the message through dating apps.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.media:credit: Logan R. Cyrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ky’Wuan Dukes, a Johnson C. Smith University student, has worked with a Democratic political action committee to reach young voters with posts on his Instagram account.

item.title: What Is Twitter Verification? A History.
item.description: Elon Musk, who recently closed a deal to acquire the social media company, could soon charge a monthly fee for the blue verification badge that indicates a Twitter account is authentic.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Elon Musk is considering charging $8 to $20 a month to verify Twitter accounts.

item.title: What Fed Rate Increases Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
item.description: Savers will benefit and borrowers can expect to pay more on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard

item.title: Fed Ushers In Fourth Jumbo Increase in Interest Rates to Fight Inflation
item.description: The Federal Reserve has now raised interest rates six times this year as it tries to quash the fastest inflation in four decades.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

item.title: CVS and Walgreens Near $10 Billion Deal to Settle Opioid Cases
item.description: The dual agreements would resolve thousands of lawsuits over the retailers’ role in the addiction crisis. But a large majority of state, local and tribal governments must sign on.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: CVS said that over the next 10 years, it would pay $4.9 billion to states and municipal governments and approximately $130 million to tribes.

item.title: Personal Tech Has Changed. So Must Our Coverage of It.
item.description: Our tech problems have become more complex, so we are rebooting the Tech Fix column to focus on the societal implications of the tech we use.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brian X. Chen has written The Times’s Tech Fix column since 2015.

item.title: Debunking Voting Misinformation About the Midterm Elections
item.description: Here are some of the main falsehoods and rumors that have spread on social media in the lead-up to Election Day.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting misinformation and rumors have been building on social media, including about ballot drop boxes and mail-in voting.

item.title: Investors Await the Fed’s Next Move
item.description: Markets expect another big interest rate increase on Wednesday. But investors are also anxious about the central bank’s coming moves.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: A Fed pivot?

item.title: The New York Times Company Adds 180,000 Digital Subscribers
item.description: The Times recorded an adjusted operating profit of $69 million for the third quarter, up from $65 million in the same period last year.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Times now has 9.33 million total subscribers, who have 10.75 million paid subscriptions across print and digital.

item.title: Republicans Float Changes to Social Security and Medicare
item.description: Democrats have seized on Republican proposals to limit retirement benefits to galvanize voters ahead of the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Rick Scott, Republican of Florida, has proposed subjecting nearly all federal spending programs to a renewal vote every year, which would make Medicare and Social Security more vulnerable to budget cuts.

item.title: Domestic Fliers Will Need Real ID Compliant Identification in 2023
item.description: For years, the government has warned travelers they will need a security-enhanced Real ID to board domestic flights, and for years the requirement has been delayed. Now they mean it.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin

item.title: Fed Faces Tough Decisions as Inflation Lingers and Economic Risks Loom
item.description: The central bank is expected to raise rates three-quarters of a point today, but what it says about its next steps will be even more important.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, and his colleagues have been rapidly increasing interest rates this year to try to wrestle inflation lower.

item.title: How the Treasury Market Predicts and Influence Interest Rates
item.description: The market for U.S. government bonds, called the Treasury market, offers predictions on the path for interest rates and the economy.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti

item.title: As Housing Costs Soar, Co-Living Makes a Comeback
item.description: The living arrangements, known as “dorms for adults,” are on the upswing after declining in the pandemic, and developers are adapting to the renewed interest.
item.dc:creator: C. J. Hughes
item.media:description: “Co-living took all the stress out of moving,” said Lindsey Tindage, who rents a room in a four-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Twitter Faces Exodus of Advertisers and Executives
item.description: At least five Twitter executives have left in recent days, as one of the world’s largest ad companies said clients should pause spending on the social media platform.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Tiffany Hsu and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: Elon Musk closed a $44 billion deal for Twitter last week and is shaking up the social media company.
